I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will synthesize lessons learned from the experiences of  
(i) the east–west partnerships for poverty reduction, (ii) community-driven development (CDD), 
and (iii) new microcredit systems, and propose how these three methods can be combined in 
the western provinces. The TA will consider previous work, and hold discussions with east–west 
pairs to improve and deepen their partnerships. It will define workable poverty-reduction project 
options using the three approaches, and incorporate a randomized evaluation process that can 
be  used  to  monitor  results  of  the  new  project  options  and  provide  feedback  for  further 
refinement.  Missions  visited  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  from  30  August–10 
September  2010 to  determine the  objectives, scope,  and  implementation  arrangements.  A 
memorandum of understanding was signed with the State Council Leading Group of Poverty 
Alleviation  and  Development  (LGOP)  and  its  Foreign  Capital  Project  Management  Center 
(FCPMC) on 10 September 2010.1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC has made significant progress in poverty reduction. Based on the official 
annual per capita poverty line of CNY1,196 ($175), the number of people living in absolute rural 
poverty has decreased from an estimated 250 million in 1978 to 35.97 million in 2010.2 However, 
significant challenges remain. Poverty has become increasingly centered in rural and more 
isolated parts of the country. It is more prevalent among vulnerable groups, such as those living 
in remote or environmentally threatened areas, the elderly, women, and members of ethnic 
minorities. Although the government is putting more resources into poverty reduction, the rate of 
decline in poverty has been slowing markedly. Recent research has indicated that new forms of 
poverty and inequality are rising.3    
 
3.  Various poverty reduction approaches have been tried in the PRC since 1995. One has 
been  the  east–west  partnerships  for  poverty  reduction.  In  1996,  the  LGOP  held  the  first 
Congress of East-West Cooperation, where it paired 10 western provinces with 13 eastern cities 
and provinces and provided guidelines for voluntary cooperation between the pairs. The eastern 
partners  are  not  required  to  provide  funding,  but  moral  suasion  is  used  by  the  national 
government to encourage support. The five types of support are (i) cash grants, (ii) industrial 
cooperation to encourage private investment from east to west, (iii) labor mobilization, (iv) social 
mobilization, and (v) staff capacity building. Eastern provinces and cities, through medium-term 
agreements, currently provide cash, training, and personnel through secondments to 15 poorer 
provinces in the western regions. However, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) research on the 
institutional aspects of the east–west partnerships completed in December 2009 showed that, in 
some cases, donations from the eastern partners had been declining because of pressures 
caused by the global financial crisis and a lack of sufficient incentives to continue increasing 
support.4 The partnerships appear to be both durable and beneficial, but can be enhanced to 
make them more effective. During a workshop to discuss the research results and subsequently

4.  A second approach to poverty reduction has been the devolution of some development 
funds and decision-making to villages, known as community-driven development (CDD). LGOP 
has conducted CDD pilot projects with ADB involvement since 1998, with six TA projects 
exceeding $4.3 million in value.6  The pilots have established the foundation for more advanced 
CDD initiatives, some of which have nongovernment organization (NGO) involvement. Field 
reviews demonstrate that CDD has resulted in more cost-effective public goods provision as a 
result  of  villagers  taking  decisions  and  managing  the  funds  themselves.  However,  some 
simplification may be needed and the legal question of allocating funds to villages when they 
are  not  registered  institutions  has  been  raised.  In  addition,  the  roles  of  NGOs  and  local 
governments may need to be refined. 
   
5.  A third approach has been microcredit, which has also been actively supported by ADB 
with numerous TA projects since the mid-1990s. Microcredit has been provided in three main 
ways: (i) by LGOP through the Agriculture Bank of China and the Agriculture Development Bank 
of China; (ii) by rural credit cooperatives to farmers; and (iii) through an expansion of institutions 
providing microcredit services, stimulated by the People's Bank of China and the China Banking 
Regulatory Commission.7 Recently, LGOP has also established village cooperative funds, which 
receive small grants and use a group guarantee model for lending to villagers. The scaling up of 
microcredit  to  increase  geographic  and  client  coverage  has  been  limited  because  of 
weaknesses in the models and regulatory restrictions. The next phase of LGOP activities in 
microcredit needs to encourage sustainability, and better engagement between small farmers 
and formal financial institutions.     
 
6.  Provinces  are  currently  considering  the  potential  to  reduce  poverty  through  a 
combination of various forms of agricultural enterprises, support for labor migration to cities, and 
improvements to schools, community centers, and other infrastructure.  However, questions 
have been raised about the sharing of profits in agricultural enterprises, labor demands and 
availability  when  farming  systems  change,  a  shift  in  focus  from  increasing  economic 
opportunities to improving household access to services, and household management of risk. 
Other  concerns  have  been  raised  about  the  environmental  sustainability  of  changes,  food 
security, market development, and the best form of agricultural enterprises, including farmer 
cooperatives. It is important that efforts to reduce poverty support not only income from farming 
but also the large number of additional smaller income-generating activities rural households 
undertake,  such  as trade  and  processing  of agricultural  products.  Reviews  are  needed  of

changes in the way intergovernmental transfers and international loan repayments are managed 
and of gender mainstreaming. The results of the pilots need to be synthesized into a set of 
guidelines for general field application. The three approaches (east–west activities, CDD, and 
microcredit) are complementary and the potential for combining them needs to be developed.  
 
7.  The proposed TA will help the PRC consolidate, combine, and expand the successful 
work done over the last 10 years. It will address some of the broader poverty questions raised 
above,  including  ensuring  gender  mainstreaming.  By  laying  down  essential  principles  for 
application of each of the three approaches and of combinations of them, the government can 
help to guide poverty reduction processes at the provincial level. In this way the effectiveness of 
the east–west partnerships can be improved, thus further reducing poverty and inequality in the 
western provinces.8   
 
8.  The government's priorities for poverty reduction were defined in the Eleventh Five-Year 
Plan, 2006–2010 and at the 17th National Congress of the Communist Party of China in 2007. 
They can also be found in ongoing consultations to develop the Twelfth Five-Year Plan and in 
the forthcoming 10-year plan for poverty reduction. The goal is to establish a harmonious 
society through balanced and people-centered development. The government has proposed a 
scientific approach to addressing growing development gaps between rural and urban areas, 
between  western provinces and coastal regions, and  between the poor and more affluent 
populations. An emphasis on rural development will continue under the Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 
and may be deepened to include rural industrial expansion.  
 
9.  The TA is fully consistent with both the government strategy for poverty reduction and 
the ADB country partnership strategy.9  The emphasis of the country partnership strategy is on 
supporting  the  PRC  in  its  work  to  ensure  environmentally  sustainable  development  and 
inclusive  growth.  This  includes  balanced  regional  development,  rural  infrastructure,  skills 
training,  financial  sector  reforms,  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  development,  and 
sustainable rural ecosystem management. All of these aspects are present in the proposed 
approach. Enhanced poverty reduction models can specifically address rebalancing, as well as 
improving rural livelihoods and reducing both poverty and household risks.     
 
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be more effective east–west partnership agreements signed 
and funded. The outcome will be enhanced systems for poverty reduction formally established 
for east-west pairs, including current east–west support areas, CDD, and microcredit.  
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Using the east–west partnerships as the anchor, the TA will study and suggest ways of 
adding CDD and microcredit to the essential elements of the east–west partnerships: grants, 
secondments, and new business investments. The TA will analyze the activities and results of 
east–west partnership activities, CDD, and microcredit, as well as gender issues, to better 
understand the key elements for success. The outputs will be reports showing (i) lessons

learned, and documentary guidelines for use of each of these three approaches to poverty 
reduction in the PRC; (ii) three models that combine the approaches; and (iii) systems to 
conduct randomized evaluations of the results of the proposed models. 
 
12.  The TA will assess and define policy, operational, institutional, and technical aspects of 
the east–west partnerships, CDD, and microcredit, incorporating gender issues throughout the 
process. Reviews of documents, detailed discussions with the FCPMC and provincial poverty 
officials, brainstorming exercises with field practitioners, and field visits and case studies in the 
western provinces will be used to produce the outputs. Specific attention will be paid to: 
 
(i)  the best way to attract private investment from eastern to western rural areas;  
(ii)  building capacity to strengthen east–west partnerships at county, township, and village 
levels;  
(iii)  experiences  of  village  cooperative  funds,  particularly  targeting  methods  for  poor 
households, and methods of expanding outreach;  
(iv)  forms of agricultural enterprises that will maximize farmer incomes and eliminate the 
need for subsidies or soft loans to enterprises or farmer cooperatives;  
(v)  improved  CDD  models  that  are  less  time-consuming  and  more  effective,  including 
involving new types of NGOs, and the role of local government; and 
(vi)  the use of the randomized evaluation methods to monitor and evaluate poverty reduction 
projects. 
 
13.  The TA will focus on establishing principles to guide poverty reduction expenditure 
related to east–west partnerships, CDD, and rural and agricultural credit. The principles will be 
based on both research and experience to date, and will be reviewed and discussed with 
stakeholders and practitioners. They may be applied at both national and provincial levels, and 
can help determine investment priorities and approaches.   
 
14.  Specific  models  blending  east–west  partnerships,  CDD,  and  microcredit  will  be 
developed, based on the principles, prior experience, and the needs of the western provinces. 
Models will need to be sufficiently flexible to enable provinces with very different needs and 
circumstances to use them. They will incorporate aspects of timing and phasing of different 
approaches to maximize synergy, and will incorporate rigorous methods of evaluation to help 
demonstrate results. They will be developed and discussed in detail with east–west pairs and 
other interested stakeholders, then modified accordingly for field application.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $425,000 equivalent, of which the government 
has requested ADB to finance $300,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF—other sources). The government will provide 
$125,000 equivalent in-kind for counterpart staff, work space and logistics support, information 
gathering, and selected training costs. The TA will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem of 
consultants, as well as training, workshops, and miscellaneous expenses. The detailed cost 
estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The  TA  is  expected  to  begin  in  December  2010  and  end  in  January  2012,  an 
implementation period of 13 months. The proposed executing agency and implementing agency 
for the TA is the FCPMC of LGOP. Other ministries and offices are expected to be consulted,

5 
including  the  Ministry  of  Finance, the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  the 
Ministry of Transport, the Ministry for Water Affairs, the Environmental Protection Agency, the 
Ministry  of  Agriculture,  and  the  four  east–west  paired  provinces  that  have  been  regularly 
engaged in the consultative process. The executing agency will provide the necessary office 
space, counterpart staff, transportation, logistical and travel arrangements, and other relevant 
services to the consultants and will arrange meetings and appointments with relevant agencies 
and organizations. 
 
17.  The  TA  will  recruit  one  international  expert  (2  person-months,  intermittent)  for 
randomized  evaluation.  Four  national  consultants  (13  person-months,  intermittent)  will  be 
recruited  for  CDD,  rural  finance,  east–west  partnership  implementation,  and  rural 
industrialization. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
international and national consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis by 
ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time 
to time). International and national consultants will work together under the direction of LGOP 
and with other national ministries and agencies and eastern and western provincial officials as 
appropriate.  The  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will finance training, 
seminars, and conferences. These costs will be administered by the executing agency using an 
advance payment facility. The executing agency has administered numerous ADB TA projects 
and five World Bank loans, and has adequate capacity to manage the funds. 
 
18.  The  TA  provides  numerous  opportunities  for  information-sharing  and  knowledge 
products. ADB will involve, on an informal basis, a group of interested technical staff, continuing 
an interdepartmental group that begun in 2009 to engage in discussions about the PRC poverty 
reduction and village participatory approaches. The group will provide guidance and support, 
including additional research references and useful international experiences, and will advise on 
draft principles and models through the project officer.  
    
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the East-West Partnerships for Poverty 
Reduction, and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will recruit one international expert (2 person-months, 
intermittent)  for  randomized  evaluation.  Four  national  consultants  (13  person-months, 
intermittent) will be recruited for community-driven development (CDD), rural finance, east–west 
partnership  implementation,  and  rural  industrialization.  The  international  and  national 
consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). International and national consultants will work together under the direction 
of the State Council Leading Group of Poverty Alleviation and Development (LGOP) and with 
other national ministries and agencies and eastern and western provincial officials.   
 
2.  All consultants will have relevant tertiary qualifications, at least 5 years’ prior experience 
in fields of work relevant to their assignment, good spoken English and the capacity to work 
closely with other colleagues to synthesize, combine, and establish successful poverty reduction 
mechanisms.  Prior  experience  in  poverty  reduction  at  the  field  level  is  critical,  as  is  an 
understanding of the operations of field-based nongovernment organizations (NGOs) in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). The international consultant must have strong knowledge of 
randomized evaluation work, preferably in academic and field settings, and prior experience in 
the PRC is highly desirable. The consultants must have good skills in working with broader 
groups to brainstorm and document results of workshops, using them to refine their reports. All 
reports and workshop summaries must be submitted in English (final reports will be in English 
and Chinese). 
 
3.  Deliverables for all consultants include: (i) an inception report containing a schedule of 
work to complete the tasks listed below and any others agreed with ADB and LGOP; (ii) drafts 
of reports, conference proceedings, training materials, and other outputs in English and Chinese 
in  accordance  with  the  inception  report;  and  (iii)  knowledge  product  drafts  to  share  with 
interested parties. The delivery dates for all deliverables will allow sufficient time for ADB and 
the executing agency to review them before finalization on or before the dates indicated in the 
design and monitoring framework for outputs.

A.  Randomized Evaluation Specialist (international, 2 person-months intermittent)  
     
4.  The scope of work is to design and train officials on impact evaluation options for east–
west poverty reduction project options incorporating CDD and microcredit using a randomized 
controlled trial. The consultant will be responsible for assisting  LGOP and relevant provinces to 
understand how to determine the best methods of designing the evaluations, supervising their 
implementation, carrying out data analysis and reporting on results. The consultant will be 
expected to work closely with all stakeholders to verify, refine, and focus the work, to maximize 
the evaluation’s learning potential. Specific tasks include: 
(i)  work with the national consultants to understand the history and experience of 
east–west  partnerships,  CDD,  and  microcredit  in  the  PRC  and  previous 
evaluations and understand the principles being proposed for each of these 
areas; 
(ii)  based on this work, advise on the most appropriate, cost-effective, and timely 
methods of designing, implementing, and analyzing the data to show results of 
the east–west enhanced partnership arrangements and complete documentation 
on this process; and 
(iii)  provide  workshops  and  training  for  stakeholders  to  best  understand  how  to 
implement the recommendations. 
 
B.  Rural Finance Specialist (national, 3 person-months intermittent) 
 
5.  The consultant will develop guiding principles for the implementation of microcredit in 
any poverty reduction project, with particular emphasis on incorporating  microcredit activities 
into east–west cooperation programs. The consultant will: 
(i)  review the extensive literature on microfinance and rural finance in the PRC to 
identify and summarize the most relevant and recent lessons for microcredit 
operations in terms of access to finance and poverty reduction; 
(ii)  review the experiences of community development funds in terms of lending, 
repayment, growth and access by the poorer households; determine the capacity 
of these organizations to grow and to meet village demand; determine viable 
mechanisms for expansion, including conversion to other institutional forms such 
as village banks, agents for commercial banks, and borrowing from commercial 
banks for onlending; assess the capacity of clients to borrow and repay under 
various interest rate scenarios; consider and comment on methods for effective 
targeting within the village; 
(iii)  recommend realistic ways of helping poorer households address risk, including 
loss of labor or assets, particularly through savings or microinsurance products; 
(iv)  consider methods and recommend principles for microcredit expansion; 
(v)  engage in and document the findings of all brainstorming and peer reviews for 
microcredit, incorporating findings into the recommendations and synthesis; and 
(vi)  provide input for the synthesis of east–west, microcredit, and CDD models. 
 
C.  Provincial Partnerships Advisor (national, 3 person-months, intermittent) 
 
6.  The  consultant  will  provide  direction  on  the  specific  types  of  work  that  east–west 
partnerships have undertaken which have been successful in poverty reduction, and to lay out 
the  principles  for  use  of  these  tools  with  microcredit  and  CDD  in  a  blended  mechanism. 
Specifically the consultant will: 
(i)  review the literature and reports within LGOP and the National Development and 
Reform Commission (NDRC) and in the public domain on east–west partnership

Appendix 3  11 
operations and results in the PRC to elicit the most relevant and recent lessons 
for  successful  and  sustainable  poverty  reduction;  pay  attention  to  
(a)  cash  grants,  (b)  training  and  capacity  building,  (c)  stimulation  of  rural 
business investment from east to west, and (d) lending from east to west and 
summarize the results in terms of lessons learned; 
(ii)  determine the best methods of persuading eastern provinces to provide sufficient 
resources to make a significant impact for longer periods; incorporate methods 
for attracting private investment from eastern to western rural areas; and build 
capacity at village, township, and county levels; 
(iii)  recommend principles for further east–west agreements and engagement;  
(iv)  engage in and document the findings of all brainstorming and peer reviews for 
east–west  partnerships,  incorporating findings  into  the  recommendations  and 
synthesis; 
(v)  create three different models, incorporating the recommendations of the other 
national consultants for CDD and microcredit into the overall sets of options; and 
(vi)  provide a final set of recommendations on  synthesized models. 
 
D.  Community-Driven Development and Gender Specialist (national, 2 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
7.  The consultant will document and develop guiding principles for gender mainstreaming 
and  implementation  of  CDD  in  any  poverty  reduction  project,  with  particular  emphasis  on 
incorporation  of  CDD  and  gender  mainstreaming  activities  into  east–west  cooperation 
programs.  The consultant will specifically: 
(i)  review  the  literature  and  documents  available  on  CDD  and  related  gender 
mainstreaming in poverty reduction projects in the PRC to elicit the most relevant 
and recent lessons in terms of village development, cost effectiveness, NGO 
engagement, and local government operations; summarize the results in terms of 
lessons learned; 
(ii)  propose  less  time-consuming  and  more  effective  CDD  models  incorporating 
gender concerns, including involvement of various types of NGOs and volunteers 
and local government, including funding and maintenance of infrastructure after it 
is created; 
(iii)  ensure  there  is  extensive  participation  in  CDD  and  gender  balancing  and 
propose methods to ensure that those who receive support are the households 
that need it most and can use it effectively; 
(iv)  recommend principles for CDD expansion, including use of local government 
funds provided directly to villages for their decision making and spending; 
(v)  engage in and document the findings of all brainstorming and peer reviews, 
incorporating findings into the recommendations and synthesis; and 
(vi)  provide input into the synthesis of east–west, microcredit, and CDD models, 
ensuring gender issues are addressed. 
 
E.  Rural Industrialization Specialist  (national, 5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
8.  The  consultant  will  identify  methods  of  rural  industrialization,  including  historic  and 
current poverty-reduction-led systems which maximize farmer incomes and eliminate the need 
for Poverty Alleviation Development Office subsidies or soft loans to enterprises or farmer 
cooperatives. In addition, the consultant will document how such models can be environmentally 
responsible and address changes in the composition of rural labor. The consultant will:

(i)  review and document alternative models of farmer engagement in the value 
chain, particularly including methods used to attract and establish both private 
and public agricultural processing and farmer cooperatives, including the four 
east–west pairs that have been working with LGOP during preparation of this TA; 
(ii)  document viable systems of farmer cooperatives operating in the PRC or which 
could be introduced, including management structure, capitalization, operations, 
methods of profit sharing, and options for technical support; 
(iii)  provide information on the incentives required to attract responsible investment 
from private sector, particularly from eastern provincial partner areas; 
(iv)  assess sources of and lender requirements for agribusiness and for farmers 
providing inputs to agribusiness;  
(v)  determine methods of extension service provision, input supply, and contracting 
between farmers and cooperatives and agribusinesses to help increase farmer 
incomes, lower their production and pricing risks, and ensure fair arrangements 
between farmers and processors; 
(vi)  assess and advise on mechanisms to improve household income derived from 
activities other than crops or animal husbandry; and  
(vii)  provide recommendations on how to develop processing in poor areas within the 
context of east–west partnerships and the expanded models, including likely 
costs and principles.
